qas.question: Major FBS teams can have lopsided victories against what kinds of lesser opponents?

answers.text: lower-tier FBS, Football Championship, or Division II schools

qas.question: Why do smaller schools want to play against major FBS teams?

answers.text: a large appearance fee and at least one guaranteed television appearance

qas.question: How many wins are required for an FBS team to be eligible for the bowl?
How many games between FBS and FCS teams count towards the FBS's bowl eligibility?
When did the College Football Playoff System begin?
Who schedules early-season conference home games?

plausible_answers.text: early season non-conference preseason home games

qas.question: I what provides a small appearance fee and a guaranteed television appearance for small schools?
How many losses before FBS team is ineligible for the ball
When did the college football playoff system and?

plausible_answers.text: because of a much higher emphasis on strength of schedule than in the Bowl Championship Series era

qas.question: Why are major teams now encouraged to schedule weaker opponents further nonconference schedule?

context: However, most of the major <b5_0>FBS teams<b5_0/> annually schedule <b6_0>early season non-conference preseason home games<b6_0/> against lesser opponents that are <a0_0>lower-tier FBS, Football Championship, or Division II schools<a0_0/>, which often result in lopsided victories in favor of the FBS teams and act as exhibition games in all but name, though they additionally provide <a1_0>a large appearance fee and at least one guaranteed television appearance<a1_0/> for the smaller school. These games also receive the same criticism as NFL exhibition games, but instead it is targeted to schools scheduling low-quality opponents and the simplicity for a team to run up the score against a weak opponent. However, these games are susceptible to backfiring, resulting in damage in poll position and public perception, especially if the higher ranked team loses, although the mere act of scheduling a weak opponent is harmful to a team's overall strength of schedule itself. Games an FBS team schedules against lower division opponents do not count toward the minimum <a2_0><b7_0>seven<b7_0/><a2_0/> wins required for bowl eligibility, and only <a3_0>one<a3_0/> game against an FCS team can be counted. With the start of the College Football Playoff system for the <a4_0><b8_0>2014<b8_0/><a4_0/> season, major teams are now discouraged from scheduling weaker opponents for their non-conference schedule <b9_0>because of a much higher emphasis on strength of schedule than in the Bowl Championship Series era<b9_0/>.
